metadata.description:
This is a free-form metadata object where extra
information can be stored. None of the information
that is contained in here should be relied on, if
and when we need to rely on it, we can promote it
to a real property.

jackalope/core/spec.title: The spec schema
jackalope/core/spec.description: This is a schema to describe the full spec

schema_map.description: This is the mapping of schema ID to schema, it is used for schema lookup

typemap.description: This is a mapping of the core type names to thier schema IDs.

target_schema.description:
This is a schema (or a reference to a schema),
of the resource being linked to. Typically this
will be just { '$ref' => '#' } to indicate that
it refers to the schema it is contained within.

data_schema.description:
This is a schema (or a reference to a schema)
of the submission data that will be accepted
by this link. In the case of a POST or PUT
method, the data is expected in the given
transport format. In the case of GET, this
should be an 'object' type schema and the
query string parameters should be checked
against it.

uri_schema.description:
This is a schema (or a reference to a schema)
of the results of the mapping of the URI-template
in the 'href' property. On the server side it
can be used to validate the value that we get,
and on the client side it can be used to check
to assure the URL being called is valid.

title.description: The human readable title of a given linkrel

metadata.description:
This is just a place for random additional metadata
that might be useful for your given implementation.
This is totally free form and can be anything you want.

description.description: A short human readable description of the linkrel

jackalope/core/linkrel.title: The 'Linkrel' schema
jackalope/core/linkrel.description:
This is the 'link' type for the hyper schema
which represents concept of links for resources.

rel.description:
This string should in some way describe the relation
of the link to the object instance. The validity of
the values is determined by the consumer of the
link data. By convention it should either be one
of well-know link relations, which can be found here
http://www.iana.org/assignments/link-relations/link-relations.xhtml,
or a URI specific to the consumer of this link data.

href.description:
This is a URI for the resource, it may also
be a URI template containing variables (using the
RoR style colon prefix). In the case of these
templates the variables should be resolved in
the context of the object instance. This means
that a template like so:
/product/:id/view
should be resolved to be this:
/product/1234/view
given an object with an 'id' property of 1234.

method.description:
The HTTP method expected by this link, if
this isn't included then GET is assumed.

jackalope/core/hyperlink.title: The 'Hyperlink' schema
jackalope/core/hyperlink.description:
This is the 'hyperlink' type for the hyper
schema which represents the concrete links
that are described with the linkrel schema.

rel.description:
This string describes the relation of the link
to the actual resource it points to. For more
details see the docs for the 'rel' element
in the jackalope/core/linkrel schema.

href.description: This is a URI of the resource the link is pointing to.

method.description:
The HTTP method expected by this link, if
this isn't included then GET is assumed.

jackalope/rest/service/non-editable.title: This is a simple REST enabled schema

jackalope/core/types/boolean.title: The 'Boolean' type schema
jackalope/core/types/boolean.description:
This is a schema for the 'boolean' type, a simple
true/false value. However the details of what is
considered true and what is considered false
are different for different languages and this
schema should take that into account based on the
language it is validating. It is important to note
that a transport format (JSON, XML, etc.) should
provide a canonical representation of true/false
so as to remove those language specific quirks.

jackalope/core/types/schema.title: The 'Schema' type schema
jackalope/core/types/schema.description:
This is a schema for the 'schema' type, it is
composed entirely of turtles all the way down.

jackalope/rest/service/crud.title: This is a simple REST enabled schema

link.description:
This is an optional hyperlink to read the resource
described, it should only ever be GET since it
is only for reading.

version.description:
This is a digest string (SHA-256) representing the current
version of the resource being pointed to. This can be used
to check to make sure that the resource has not changed
since it was last referred too.

jackalope/rest/resource/ref.title: The 'Resource Ref' schema
jackalope/rest/resource/ref.description:
This is meant to be a way to represent
references to resources, it can be a convient
way to refer to a resource only by it's ID
and therefore save bandwidth.

type_of.description:
This is the schema URI for the type of
resource that this refers too.

$id.description:
This is the lookup ID which can be
used to locate the resource.

additional_properties.description:
This is a set of key/value pairs where the
key is a property name and the value is
a schema (or a reference to a schema)
represented as an 'object' instance. These
properties however are optional and do not
need to exist in order to pass validation.

items.description:
This is a schema (or a reference to a schema)
represented as an 'object' instance, which will
be used to validate all the values in the object.

properties.description:
This is a set of key/value pairs where the
key is a property name and the value is
a schema (or a reference to a schema)
represented as an 'object' instance. All
these properties are required and must be
present in order to pass validation.

jackalope/core/types/object.title: The 'Object' type schema
jackalope/core/types/object.description:
This is a schema for the 'object' type, which is
a set of key/value pairs. The term 'object' is
derived from Javascript, but this is the same as
a hash in Perl, a dictionary in Python, an
associative array in PHP, a Hashtable, a Map,
all of which are essentially the same thing.

jackalope/rest/service/read-only.title: This is a simple read-only REST enabled schema

max_items.description: The maximum number of items in the array

is_unique.description: A boolean to indicate of the list should contain no duplicates

min_items.description: The minimum number of items in the array

items.description:
This is a schema (or a reference to a schema)
represented as an 'object' instance, which will
be used to validate all the elements in a list.

jackalope/core/types/array.title: The 'Array' type schema
jackalope/core/types/array.description:
This is a schema for the 'array' type, which is
basically just a list of other values. The list
by default are heterogenous, but using the
optional 'items' property it is possible to
constrain the list to be more homogenous.

literal.description: A literal value that must match exactly

pattern.description: A regular expression that can be checked against the string

format.description: This is one of a set of built-in formatters

enum.description: This is an array of possible acceptable values, it should contain no duplicates

min_length.description: The minimum length of the string given

max_length.description: The maximum length of the string given

jackalope/core/types/string.title: The 'String' type schema
jackalope/core/types/string.description:
This is a schema for the 'string' type, which is
any value that is explcitly cast as a string. This
means that it can be an entirely numeric string,
as long it is cast as a string based on the details
of the implementation language. As with 'boolean'
values, any transport format (JSON, XML, etc.) is
expected to provide some kind of way to explicitly
cast a given value as a given type so as to make
for better interoperability.

jackalope/core/types/null.title: The 'Null' type schema
jackalope/core/types/null.description:
This is a schema for the 'null' type, it is not
so much the absence of a value, but a value that
explicity represents no value.

title.description: The human readable title of a given schema

description.description: A short human readable description of the schema

extends.description:
This is a schema (or a reference to a schema)
represented as an 'object' instance. The exact
details of extension are described elsewhere.

links.description:
This is an object of 'linkrel' objects, the purpose
of which is to provide a way to map services
to the objects described in a schema. In OOP terms,
you can think of them as methods, while the schema
describes the instance structure.

jackalope/core/types/any.title: The 'Any' type schema
jackalope/core/types/any.description:
This is a schema for the 'any' type, it is the
base schema type, all other schema types extend
this one. Therefore this schema defines the
base elements that are in all schemas, both
required and optional.

jackalope/core/ref.title: The reference schema
jackalope/core/ref.description:
This is an object to represent a 'reference'
to another object. By convention, the value
stored in $ref is the 'id' of another object.
Additionally the value of '#' is also
acceptable to indicate a reference to
the containing schema.
When a reference is encountered, it should
be resolved and replaced by the value it
references. There are no explict dereferencing
operations. The exact details of when a
reference is resolved and how are an implemention
detail and out of the scope of this spec.

jackalope/rest/service/discoverable.title: This is a base discoverable REST enabled schema

greater_than.description: A number must be greater than this value

less_than_or_equal_to.description: A number must be less than or equal to this value

greater_than_or_equal_to.description: A number must be greater than or equal to this value

enum.description: This is an array of possible acceptable values, it should contain no duplicates

less_than.description: A number must be less than this value

jackalope/core/types/number.title: The 'Number' type schema
jackalope/core/types/number.description:
This is a schema for the 'number' type, which is
a numeric value that includes floating point
numbers as well as whole numbers. The level of
floating point precision and the possible size
of a number are platform and implementation
specific. However the spec reserves the right
to possibly put a cap on this at a later date
to help improve interoperability.

links.description:
This is a list of links which represent the
capabilities of given resource, the consumer of
the resource can use these links to perform
different actions.

jackalope/rest/resource.title: The 'Resource' schema
jackalope/rest/resource.description:
The is a 'wrapper' of sorts for resources
as viewed from the concept of the web and
REST. It is mostly intended to be extended
where the 'body' property is overriden with
the schema of our choice.

body.description:
This is the body of the resource, it is of type
'any' for now, but it as this schema is meant to
be extended and this property overridden, this is
basically whatever you need it to be.

version.description:
This is a digest string (SHA-256) representing the current
version of the resource. When the resource is updated
the version should be compared first, to make sure
that it has not been updated by another.

id.description:
This is the ID of the given resource, it is
assumed to be some kind of string, which should
still just work fine even for numeric values.
This is expected to be the lookup key for
resources in a resource repository.

greater_than.description: A integer must be greater than this value

less_than_or_equal_to.description: A integer must be less than or equal to this value

greater_than_or_equal_to.description: A integer must be greater than or equal to this value

enum.description: This is an array of possible acceptable values, it should contain no duplicates

less_than.description: A integer must be less than this value

jackalope/core/types/integer.title: The 'Integer' type schema
jackalope/core/types/integer.description:
This is a schema for the 'integer' type, which is
an extension of the 'number' type to not include
floating point numbers. It handles all the same
additional properties, but overrides them here
such that they will only operate on valid integer
values.
